title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY03 Round15   Zimbabwe vs Netherlands
motion: This House believes that major tourist destinations should significantly limit the number of tourists that can visit.

argument_units.text: This is just Mason's time. Thank you. I'll begin my speech in 3, 2, one. To be a Brazilian woman living in the heart of Rio means that more than just fancy tourist aesthetics and surf life over anything, it means an increase in price of your children's baby formula because there's nothing you can do about it. It means making ultimatums between keeping your only home and having to sell it off to greedy capitalist faces in order to feed your family. It means ending up like the children in Bali competing for drops of water. It means having to grapple with the idea that the tourist market makes a joke out of your suffering and the living proof of that walks across your favela every day in millions just to take a photo of it.

Proposition says when it gets this terrible, we ought to take immediate action. I will argue, one, on principle, secondly, on the economic harms of the standard of living, and my second speaker will extend on the extended harm of tourism. But our two points on set-up.

On the count of the model, what do we look at? We say our policy is two-pronged. Firstly, we significantly limit by placing caps on attendance in various ways. We say, firstly, by restricting numbers to entry. We do this in just the same way Lord Howie Island in Australia restricts the islands to 400 people per night as of 2019. But secondly, through pre-bookings and specific tourist restrictions, right? We say we allow certain individuals at each point in time to enter major tourist destinations and make travel-specific visas to that very major tourist destination. But on the second layer, we say we aggressively promote other tourist destinations. We say we do this through the increased advertisements of smaller tourist destinations, but secondly, through promoting virtual tourism. We say in the same way Thievelu did this when the island was under imminent threats of sinkage. We say this is something that is important. But why then do we think this is the best and the only form of regulation? We say historically, due to the direct conflict that exists between the very purpose of tourism, which is to invade the natural space and be its parasite, and the core function of regulation, which is to limit invasion in one way or another, be it banning snorkeling in Guantanamo, be it the jail time for noise in Venice, or be it the banning of Airbnbs and hotel construction in Barcelona. We say that the governments have been unable to regulate without taking away from the adventure of tourism in itself. We say significant limitation, however, is unique in its ability to simply reduce the number of people that can invade this particular space. We say that's something that's important. So first, let's talk on principle. But before we do that, let's talk about a little bit of some pretext here.

We say that there's a long-standing history of tourism that has scarred and violently struck at the souls of locals within major tourist destinations. We say that this has served as the impetus for new untapped levels of hate and vitriol towards mass tourism by these locals. We say that the hate is closely tied to the idea of having too many tourists, and it conjures up feelings of unsafety and anger. We say in Spain, locals have been gathering up at tourist sites to throw stones at those particular locals, at those particular tourists. We say in Bali, we've seen violent protests and violent protests erupting at the end of the day, right? What then becomes the premise here? We say that the mass existence of tourists in the land of locals is a triggering and a frightening scene. We say government's responsibility in this instance should be to significantly reduce in order to put those people's minds at ease. What's the claim therein? We say the claim of this principle therein is two-pronged. One, we say that there is government obligation towards responsiveness, right? But secondly, we say that there is proactiveness of the government in response to the civil uproar that is occurring. What's the wash here? Why do we think there are no pragmatic benefits that are likely to materialize on their side? Because we say the tourism industry in itself is going to face severe damage in future because of this vigil. We see that people are already scared to travel to these areas, particularly because of the anger that's already there. So we think at the moment in which you don't resolve this, we don't see a world in which the pragmatic benefits they are going to argue for are going to materialize in the long term. So what do we want you to note critically? Note that we value the paternalistic utilitarian role of government in the instance where the populace can rationalize this decision. But in a world, however, where the people are greatly emotionally traumatized, where the people are hurting, where the people are bleeding, we think that government has to value putting the minds of those particular people at ease. They have to value then helping those particular people, right? What then becomes the proof of outcome here here we say in the instances that we don't follow this principle we think we then see followers of like mass citizen discontent right we see a lot of civil disarray because a lot of people are generally angry about the ideas and everything that's been going on i think that's something that is terrible but principally on its own right why is it important to follow this principle? Because you feel trust in your state, you say you feel the discontent and you fulfill that discontent of citizens who've been always feeling like the government has been not acting towards these things, right? Principally, those people feel safe and they feel like, you know, the state has fulfilled their obligation to the people. And we say that in itself is something that is very important that we ought to preserve.

But the second argument is on why significant limiting in itself in improving the standard of living. But before I take that, let me take a few more. If there's already so much fear for tourists traveling to these locations, why are we not going to see a gradual drop-off in the number of tourists? Why do we need to impose these strict government restrictions? So, I think we've already spent a long time explaining why that's something that's necessary. I don't think that's necessarily relevant. But when we talk about the significant limiting in improving the standard of living, what's the premises here? We say that over-tourism has harmed the standard of living for locals. We say that the locals have been priced out of the market, and this is manifested in multiple ways. One, we say it's manifested in the skyrocketing of prices for basic necessities. Notice how locals are forced to live on less than the bare minimum. They have lack of access to cheap food, clothing for your children. E.g., we saw this in the Bahamas, where there's a 47.5% increase in prices in every tourist season for them. And these prices are only getting worse and worse. Why is this so? Because one, there's an influx of tourists that jack up the demand and cause demand-pull inflation. But secondly, because tourists are generally perceived as financial stable people. And so companies generally have an incentive to increase prices so as to capitalize on the profits of as much as possible, right? But secondly, we say that locals are subject to forced displacement. We say that the rental prices and the housing costs are pushed up significantly, making it difficult for locals to often live in those areas. In New York, an urban tourist-heavy city, they average up to 80% more in housing costs making it difficult for locals to often live in those areas. In New York, an urban tourist-heavy city, they average up to 80% more in housing costs compared to other neighboring cities such as Jersey City. This happens because the demand for housing by tourists is often pushing out those particular... forcing a lot of landowners to maximize their profit by changing their business models from orienting towards the local market to orienting towards the tourist market to orienting towards the tourist market and pushing out those particular locals. We think secondly, we think locals are getting bought out of their houses. They prey on the despise of these particular locals for that money and use that land to then develop more tourist attractions that way they can benefit off of profit.
How is this harmful? Because we say people get displaced en masse to worse off areas. We say areas without functional surrounding essential services.

Areas like hospitals for healthcare and schools for education. We say that this hurts the locals. Weigh this harm on its self-amplifying nature. We say because tourism continues to expand and send people into even worse off areas, it means that people keep on getting worse and displaced even more and more. And this is something that is generally harmful. But lastly, we say the outpricing of locals renders that employment contracts useless at the end of the day. This is because the minimum wage jobs that these people are earning barely cover the high cost of living in these touristified areas. This is worse for lowly paid workers in the appendaging industries because this continues the price increase versus like the low wages continues to make them suffer within these areas. but how then does significantly limiting deal with this on the comparative note here one we say significantly limiting deals with overall pricing because there's no demand pool inflation so we think because there are less people we think the prices are much less but secondly we say that the businesses reduce like prices in order to cater to those local people because that's where their most that their profit base relies right to say that because now we've got more locals and locals are more more profitable like markets to invest into we're likely going to reduce our like prices to engage those people right but secondly we say deals with displacement because landlords have no incentive to increase the rent as like the main consumer base again are locals right but secondly we say airbnbs and other housing structures are likely not going to change the ways they do their structures because they understand how they're going to be able to attain more money from that particular consumer base. We say what's better for those particular individuals who are better for the locals, and we think that this is something that is incredibly important on our side. Proud to vote.

Proposition refuses to acknowledge that for many people, tourism is their livelihood. In Bangkok, the industry supports a salary of 50 million people. The population depends on it to pay for their rent, their groceries, and their children's education. Propaganda has to defend a large part of the population losing their job with no alternative. I am so proud to oppose.

In my speech, I will prove two things. Firstly, why tourism is the only viable economic stimulus of the region. And secondly, why tourism is crucial for regional development, such as infrastructure. But first, let's start with framing.

What do we think that these tourist destinations look like? We think most of these destinations enormously benefit from tourism economically. So, for example, in my tourism directly or indirectly brings in 70% of the GDP on the island. Limiting tourism means robbing people from their income and their opportunities to build a future.

We think it is likely that alternative measures will be implemented to combat the negative effects of tourism because the local population wants to keep their environment clean and tidy for their own enjoyment. So this looks like promoting off-season travelling more and having security on heritage sites. We see that this is worked in, for instance, the Colosseum, where more security has significantly decreased the amount of tourists that have attempted to vandalise the walls.

Okay. No, thank you. Now, quickly moving on to rebuttal. Firstly, on that principle, I just want to note here that it fully relies on the practical outcome of the debate. As in, they say that the reason that the government should care about this is because the population is hurting really bad. At the point that we prove to you that the population is hurt more on their side, we also take this principle. And then on the practical argument about the economy, I want to note that what we see is that often only the tourist products are inflated. So for example, the restaurant prices are inflated, but groceries aren't. Hotel prices are inflated, but homes aren't. And we tell you that even if the prices are high, on our side, there is a salary to pay these prices to begin with. On our side, there is none. Before I move on to the first argument, I will take a break.

Is it not the reason why other industries like factories and farms can't develop? It's because there is tourism and there is no way for these industries to come in to develop these areas. There are structural reasons why other industries cannot develop, and this is what I will explain in my second argument. For example, they don't have the natural resources. For example, they don't have the space.

Okay, so now moving on to the first argument, which is about economic stimulation. Why do we think tourism is crucial for the economy in these regions? Two reasons. First of all, because there are many visitors in the region making use of services, that already means a lot of money comes into the region. But second of all, tourists are willing and able to spend more money than the local population. Tourists generally tend to be more wealthy, save up for vacation, and spend their money impulsively. This has two positive effects then on the local economy. A, it simply means there is a lot more demand for labor. The local population on our side is able to pay for rent and food by working in restaurants where tourists eat, hotels where they sleep, and museums that they visit. But B, apart from there being more jobs, these jobs are relatively well paid. Tourists tend to spend lots of money that for higher prices can be asked than for locals. This is why in markets and for taxis you tend to be charged more when you are a tourist. And that also means that local business owners get more money and are able to pay their employees well.

These destinations are often economically reliant on the tourism industry for two reasons. One, tourists make up the far majority of the consumer base. Hotels, souvenir shops and bars are all unable to make profit without a constant stream of customers. But two, in these destinations, it is incredibly hard to start up an entirely new industry directly dealing with their POI. Why is this? Four reasons. First of all, most people are taught to work in service and hospitality jobs. It is incredibly hard to in one go retrain the majority of the population, let alone have experts do the higher up work. But B, it requires an insane amount of capital and time. To specialize in a new industry on a large scale and become actual competition in the market, you need to build entire factories, offices, find customers on a large scale. This is undoable. C, a lot of retains don't have the natural resources to specialize in alternative industries. So for example, the Netherlands is specialized in agriculture because we have very fertile land. The Middle East is specialized in oil because they have a lot of oil fields. And many of these tourist destinations don't have any of these natural resources. Think the Maldives, think Venice, right? And lastly, capital and space are zero-sum. So the city center only has a limited amount of accessible space. So if there is a building, you can either make it an office in a hotel. Historically, they have been making hotels of this, therefore there is no base to go from, there is no other industry to invest in. All of this also means that investors will never invest capital into these regions, but will always prefer the neighboring regions that doesn't have all of these problems. So then what is the impact? On proposition,
masses of people now find themselves unemployed, unable to make rent, buy food, and buy clothes. At the moment that you have

no income and you have lost your job, your situation worsens drastically within no time, maybe even becoming homeless. And even if they do find a job in another industry, it's likely to be worse, likely to be paid worse, making a big part of the population still struggle with financial issues. Society will then end up in a negative spiral of economic recession, because at the point that the population has little money to spend, there's less demand for products and also less demand for jobs. Now moving on to the second argument, which

is about regional development, because tourism is the single reason that the streets are clean, that the streets have lights, and that there are no holes in the streets. So why is there only regional development? Because of tourism. This is because of the incentive of the government. Because as we've proven, tourism creates a lot of economic revenue. And governments are dependent on tourism for their tax income. This looks like issuing visas. This looks like taxes on profit and product taxes. Therefore they have to keep on developing the region. Proposition takes the incentive for the government to care away because the region is no longer an area that brings in money. What do we think then that regional development looks like? This looks like building infrastructure such as high speed rails, better quality and cleaner roads, and the installation of ATM. This is necessary to keep tourists coming. Roads with holes, dirty streets, and a lack of streetlights deter tourists. On proposition, the government can let dirt roads be dirt roads and keep dark alleys without streetlights. Note then that the infrastructure benefits locals. We see this, for example, in Spain, where a railroad between Barcelona and Montserrat was developed to connect tourist destinations, but the 12 villages located in the 15 kilometers in between these tourist destinations now can also easily take the train. Note that this also deals with their case, where they say that prices tend to become a lot more expensive. On our side, it's easier to live outside of the city. But second of all, you get more developed products and services. Tourists will demand a certain quality of products that they are used to, that otherwise would not be imported into the area. This looks like medicine, right? This looks like higher quality goods. The local community now gets access to these higher quality products and services. So what does this then mean to the debate? Infrastructure has a huge positive impact on the lives of the local population. It means it's easier to live further away from the city and travel to work by public transport. Think, for example, the train in Spain. It means your streets are less likely to be covered in trash. It gives people access to medicine and conveniences, but forcing them to move or spend money on going elsewhere to get basic services done. Pano, in our side, the 50 million people that are living in Bangkok aren't left in the dark, but they can keep sustaining their lives. For all these reasons, I am so proud to oppose.

Chair, three things in this speech. I'll give you direct responses to what side the opposition is in this debate, and I'll integrate the rest of the reputations within my extension. So what are the few things that I think particularly don't make sense on their side that don't allow them to claim the benefits that they claim are going to happen?

First is on the idea of employment. Why do we think this is something that isn't as valuable given the characterization that you get from my first speaker? We say that in the instance that individuals are actually employed within these industries, we talk about the low wages that these individuals earn within these industries. This is to say that even if these individuals are particularly employed, they still can't afford basic staples within those cities. But secondly, we think there's a structural flaw in the argumentation and they tell us that there's comparatively different pricing. This is to say that groceries are cheaper than hotels. We think this is something that's untrue within major tourist destinations. Why? Because we think that even those hotels themselves buy those groceries that they're going to be using for the tourists that particularly live within those Airbnbs and hotels. So we think that there's still an incentive for those prices to still hike. But thirdly, we said that these tourists don't just go to hotels. We think those tourists also eat and buy those groceries that are existing within the streets of those cities. So we still think there's no such thing as the comparative pricing that exists. But secondly, we said that even if those individuals are actually employed, we think that in the vast majority of instances, because tourism is a seasonal employment type of like industry, we say that most of those individuals get laid off when the tourists don't particularly go there. We say that when most tourists come within the holiday seasons, we think for the greater part of the year, individuals are unemployed enemies. This is to say that even if individuals significantly drop in the number of individuals that go to those tourist destinations during like the seasons where people go in large numbers, we still think that the impact of individuals being laid off is still mitigated on their side. We don't see why that's something that's beneficial. But secondly,

it's on the idea of the GDP that you get from these economies. They say that you get more infrastructural development within these cities. Why do we think this is valuable? Two reasons. First, we know that the locals that exist within these countries don't benefit from that infrastructural development. Why? Because we think that the overt damage that these tourism industries? Because you think of the overt damage that these tourism industries have incurred because of the large amount of people that visit, means that a huge part of the income that these countries make are usually directed towards maintenance. You say this is the reason why Hawaii as an island, even when they get like five million dollars within like the GDP that they get from the tourism industry. It's still an underdeveloped state within itself because of how much capital is actually driven back into maintaining the harms of over-tourism within the island. We've seen this happen within cities like Bali in Indonesia, where a lot of the pollution that you get from cruise ships is actually affecting the water supplies within those cities. This necessitates government to spend a huge portion of the amount of income that they get from tourism in actually purifying the water that individuals are supposed to get within those states, which means that there is a marginal benefit that you get from tourism and we're going to integrate with you in our extension as to why we think that particularly becomes problematic. What are you going to get in terms of extension within this speech? Two things.

First, the extension of the extended harm on tourism on other industries. We say that the act of tourism itself is something that constitutes a harm to the environment that it's actually partaking in. We say that when scuba divers go into the waters of the Guadalupe Islands, we think using things such as attractants and cages actually harms the species that exist within those waters. We think there's an extended harm, therefore, when you have the variety of people, a large number of people actively dumping cages into the waters of Guaranupe. We've seen this happen when there's a large mass of people that walk within the Great Wall of China, which has necessitated two-thirds of it to be unfit for tourism because of the structural damage that they've incurred. Why do we think this is true? We say that the more that you have all about tourism and the high influx of people that actually damage this infrastructure, it makes it increasingly difficult for these governments to maintain them. And we think this is something that becomes harmful for three reasons. Therefore, we think, firstly, the damage to these sites in most instances is irreversible. This is to say that two-thirds of the Great Wall of Chima are still closed down today. We think the same happens with the Guadalupe Islands where they got closed in the early years of 2023, two dates they haven't been reopened. The harm, therefore, is that if they value the employment that you get from tourism, we think when you have over-tourism, you are likely to get a complete closure of those infrastructure in the instance that there's an extensive damage on the infrastructure a complete closure of those infrastructure in the instance that there is an overt damage or like there is an extensive damage on the infrastructure that they have within that particular site. What that means is that you are unable in the long term to continue to have that employment that they value on their site so much. I think this is something that they need to consider because I think in the long term these tourist sites are unable to provide the type of employment and infrastructural support that they want. But secondly, we say that there's an extended harm even on the environment itself. We say that the cruise ships that land in the beaches of Venice particularly harm the damage, like the water supply that you get within those particular cities. We say in cities like Bali, within Indonesia, when you have a lot of cruise ships actually polluting the waters, what that means is that individuals that exist within that city don't have access to clean water. What is this to say? We think this is an extended harm that only happens when you have over-tourism. Why? Because we think that when you have less cruise ships going to those particular cities, you are likely to have manager performs of pollution within the waters that exist within Venice. We think that's the comparative there so what it means that you have less spending on like we have less spending on like actually accounting for the harms of tourism but rather spending into the infrastructure that you actually have within those cities we think this is something that you then get within that what is this to say he said that the extended harm on that environment itself is something that constitutes a harm to the how to how individuals are able to end that life within those cities. We say that when individuals can get access to clean water, we think the government should prioritize those individuals having that access as opposed to having like pleasantries from tourism. We think this is something that they needed to prioritize. But that you say that there's even an extended harm within the sense of security within these cities. This is to say that an increase in the large populations in cities such as Paris and Barcelona has led to a spike in crime rates within those cities. We think individuals or the locals don't feel safe because there's always large crowds parading within the streets that have led to instances of high crime within those cities, right? What is this to say? We think that government therefore is also necessitated to increase their spending on ensuring security for tourists that go to those cities, but also for the locals that exist within those cities. And we think that's an extended harm that side opposition needs to take care of within their side of the page. We think this is something that they need to engage. But then before I get to how significant limitations solve these problems, I'll take you. For this point, work, you have to explain why the alternative measures don't work with people both.

Alright, so we think that the alternative measures don't particularly work because we think that in your case you already show how, for example, promoting people going for off-season tourism particularly means that you still have individuals particularly being limited in numbers because we don't see how individuals can go to off-season when they still have the opportunity to go in-season, right, when they go on holidays. We don't see how individuals can go to off-season when they still have the opportunity to go in-season, right, where they go on holidays. We don't see how you're able to achieve that without limiting individuals from going to those tourist destinations during the seasons, right? But second, we say in your regulation, you actually remove the essence of tourism itself. We don't think you can be a scuba diver when you are not allowed to enter the waters of cages and shoot like the species that you want to explore from a distance. We think tourism itself loses its essence in that instance. We think this is something that you need to consider. But why do significant limitations actually solve this problem? First, we say that less participation within the acts of tourism per day limits the amount of harm individuals can inflict on the environment, limits the amount that individuals can inflict on those particular tourist sites. To say that you don't have to close down the Inca Trail in cities like Peru because of the amount of damage that you have within those cities. I think this is something that you needed to consider. But lastly, we said that the moment that government doesn't attend to the uproar of these protesters, it's likely to escalate. In the early 2000s, people were carrying banners. Today, people are throwing stones at tourists. We're all for the government's response.

Proposition thinks tourists are parasites, but a relationship that relies on a trade of goods and services that only one group can provide and the other enjoys in exchange for money in this case, that is not parasitism, that is symbiosis. And that is the whole crux of our case. It's that these people cannot live the way that they live without tourism, that they cannot have a decent life without it, that they are dependent, just as tourists are dependent on places to go to.

So in my speech, firstly, some repair on our two arguments, firstly on the economic benefits of tourism, and then secondly on our development of infrastructure, then some rebuttal, and finally an extension on why tourism inherently increases income quality. So, firstly, in terms of repair, what do they tell us about our arguments? So, firstly, they tell us that people are, they tell us that none of our economic benefits are valuable at the point at which you're not getting proper wages, right? We think that you are getting proper wages for two reasons, right? So, firstly, local business owners have empathy towards people who are from their own region, from their country, right? Secondly, employees just work more productively when they are satisfied in their wage at the point at which you are making a ton of money off of tourists. The benefit that you get from your employees being fast, being able to out-compete other restaurants because they're satisfied, because they're able to afford nice meals and everything and not be malnourished, so they can't get the food there on time. We think that that benefit far outweighs the money that you would be paying them at the point at which you're making so much. Secondly, what else do they tell us? They tell us that our benefits to infrastructure do not matter because most of the money is spent on maintenance. Note that this is not true. Most of the money is spent on establishing the infrastructure in the first place. Because often, places that have a lot of tourism are not very well connected. They are not super interconnected with other regions, which is why they're unique, which is why they have so much tourism in their first place, right? And obviously, the most cost comes when you're first laying that rope. Retouching it costs much less. So the benefits are way, way bigger because of tourism. Without tourism, governments simply don't have an incentive to do this, often because, again, these regions are not inherently super-connected through other regions, through other areas of the economy.

Okay, now on rebuttal. What do they give us on their principle, right? They give us, well, it's not really a principle, but they mostly give us analysis on why people hate tourists, why there's so much conflict between locals and tourists. Firstly, we think this is grossly exaggerated, because if people were really throwing rocks at tourists everywhere, and I think tourists would pretty quickly be told about this by other tourists, by their friends and family, read about it on the internet, they would stop coming there gradually, right? I am not sure why the government needs to intervene here and suddenly cut tourism down, just suddenly creating a vacuum in the economy. We see that this has happened before when tourists feel unsafe, as they tell you that they do in these situations. For instance, in Egypt, when there was a lot of terrorism, tourists stopped coming pretty quickly. So if they really want tourists to stop coming, then that's already going to happen anyways. So we didn't think that it was fair for them to characterize certain parts of the economy being inflated and certain parts being uninflated. That's not how it works exactly.

But on tourism, we told you that it's very important for you to cater to the economic depletion that happens because the land is dying. And we think at a point at which it dies to an extent at which we can't solve it, we're into irreversibility. There's no going back on this. And everyone eventually suffers in the world of opposition. Proud to oppose.

title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY03 Round17   Finland vs Austria
motion: This House believes that major tourist destinations should significantly limit the number of tourists that can visit.

argument_units.text: By limiting the number of the tourists, it is the only way to save the lives of the locals. In the best case, tourists are annoying, but in great quantities, they are a scourge to the earth. Two arguments in the proposition case. Firstly, improving the life of the locals. And secondly, reshaping travel culture and combating climate change. Now, into the frame. We tell you, PAC, that the locals are the most important stakeholder in the debate. Because they are the people that still have to live in these major tourist destinations even when the tourists leave. They are the people that pay taxes to maintain these destinations. They are also the people that are building these cities throughout generations. They are, most importantly, the people that will have to stay there and deal with whatever consequences the tourists leave afterwards. Therefore, I urge the panel to care the most about locals in this debate. So now, how can we win this debate? Two things. First, we can prove to the panel that locals are better on our side of the house. Or then we can prove to the panel that locals are better on our side of the house, or then we can prove to the panel that climate change is significantly combated on our side of the house. Both ways, by proving either, we will win this debate.

So now into the model. We tell you that on our side of the house, we are proposing a model where tourists will have to apply for an access pass to come to these cities. They will have to pay for an access fee that these host governments can choose themselves. And this fee will then be used to maintain these destinations after these tourists leave. And there will only be a limited amount of passes that are solved within a single time frame.

So now, into the first argument. So we tell you, Pam, that on our side of the house, we're directly improving the life of locals. What do we mean by this? Three parts in this argument. Firstly, we're telling you that we're directly reducing the disturbance of locals. What do we mean by this? Three parts in this argument. Firstly, we're telling you that we're directly reducing the disturbance of locals. What do we mean by this? This makes the lives of the locals extremely hard because it's very hard for me to get to a hospital, for example, to see my mother, if there's an excessive amount of crowd near the Colosseum and I have to get through the Colosseum to the hospital. It's not convenient for the locals. It's not great for the locals. Moreover, these tourists leave a significant amount of trash and litter and all kinds of disposable material behind. Moreover, they also consume much more than these locals. They consume much more plastic. They consume six times the amount of water than the locals consume. And this is not sustainable for these major tourist destination cities. Moreover, there is noise. There's significantly more noise with overcrowdings, with just, you know, the people walking through the streets or the crowd shouting when they see the Eiffel Tower because it's just so great for them. And even, no, you know, the people walking through the streets or the crowd shouting when they see the Eiffel Tower because it's just so great for them. And even, no, thank you, and even if we do not take these examples into consideration, just because I live in an apartment building and my rich neighbor landlord is renting their apartment continuously to tourists, when they continuously rent their Airbnb to tourists that do not care about regulation, that party every single night. It's very hard for me as a student to study for my medical school entrance exam. We tell you that all of these are directly reduced on our side of the house, because just by limiting the sheer quantity of tourists that visit, all of these problems are already significantly reduced on our side of the house. But now, secondly, we're also reducing the indirect harms that these tourists cause to these major tourist destinations. We tell you that these tourists, with their share quantity, they are directly pushing up the prices of all services. This means, for example, food prices, gas, every single thing that you can imagine are going up because there's so many of these tourists in these places that you know Everyone can just charge so much more but we tell you that this still does not benefit the locals Even if opposition tells you that why we tell you that the only people that are actually Benefiting from these are already the wealthy we tell you that it's only the rich landlords, those who have owned this property for already 100 years or big international or regional corporations. It's only these three kinds of people that actually benefit from there because they already own this property in these major, you know, tourist destinations. They have property there and they can rent them with extremely high prices to these local businesses. We tell you that these people will rent with a high price, and this makes the people who actually are in these places, these local business owners, they have to sell at a significantly higher price if they want to make any kind of return or profit from this. And this, again, makes the lives of those who don't do this much harder because you have to now pay at a much higher price. But you don't have this because you are a local. And we tell you that only tourists are able to do this because they are only temporary. They come for a fixed amount of one, two days. They're able to afford this because they think that, okay, I'm going to pamper myself for two days, pay a bit more. It doesn't matter for them. But it matters for these locals that have to stay there even when the tourists leave. That is not true in the status quo. The status quo is so that these tourist destinations, these cities are flooded with tourists everywhere. There is no local or tourist quarter because all of this is a tourist quarter. Everywhere in the city, there is so much demand from the tourists that all of the prices are spiked up. Moreover, we also tell you that this problem manifests even more when you look at housing prices. Because I already gave you the example of people renting more and more Airbnb's because they know that hotels cannot accommodate they simply cannot accommodate all of the people that want to go to paris that want to go to rome that want to go to bernice it's simply they know that they have they can you know rent more and more airbnbs at you know limited amount of time it's for them it's even more profitable to maybe keep them for a few days without anyone leaving living there then you know they are able to do that and you know still rent at a much higher price and, you know, still rent at a much higher price because when they know, when someone rents it, it's so much more profitable this way than to rent for a longer period of time for, you know, a local.

I tell you that on our side of the house, these problems are significantly less. And thirdly, I also tell you that we're preserving identity and cultural heritage. We tell you that on our side of the house, we're directly reducing the harm caused to natural sites like we see in France, we have the La Salle caves, where that had to be closed, they had to be shut down because the enormous amount of tourists that visit us day in, day out because of the excessive carbon dioxide that was, the humidity of people, the human-caused erosion. These are all factors that cannot be, that
simply cannot be reduced through other measures. And there's also not to mention vandalism,

you know, trashing, littering, taking pieces off these natural sites. And this cannot be reduced with any other means. This cannot simply be done by, you know, adding more police, because there's so many people, one police or a few more police won't do anything. We tell you that only by reducing the number of people can we actually do something if it is, for example, humidity or excessive carbon dioxide. And our side of the house is telling that it's extremely important for the locals because they have value to them. If I'm a person who grew up every day walking past the Eiffel Tower, every day you know all of my childhood memories are attached to this one place, when this place represents part of my national identity or something that I have national pride towards, it is not fair for these locals to be ripped away from this and even if you don't believe that this is beneficial for the locals, we also give you this alternative point of view that this is also beneficial for the tourists if you take good care about them. We tell you that tourists will want to come as long as the Eiffel Tower is there, as long as the Eiffel Tower is in good condition, and on their side of the house, because they do not want to limit, because they do nothing to stop the deterioration of these, tourists will, in the future, not even want to come to these places, and therefore, even whatever beneficial economic impacts that they are providing

will not happen. So now to summarize three parts in my speech that I've told you. Firstly, we're reducing direct harms to these locals. Noise, overcrowding, traffic jams, everything. Secondly, we are pushing down the prices because we're making these economies reshape around locals and not the prices that toys give. And thirdly, we're also giving them back the right to these natural sites. And therefore, life is better on our side of the house. I urge the panel to vote for us.
Panel, we on-side off don't limit the people, we limit harms.

In my speech I will bring up two major arguments. Why there is no alternative industry and second, why this will lead to mass unemployment and economic regression. In our second speech we will explain how this motion leads to massive loss of current and future infrastructure. But first some responses regarding the quantity of tourists versus the quantity of tourists. On our side, we still can have and likely will have regulations and incentives for tourists to behave well. These also rebut all of your points. Note, panel, that the proposition cannot claim we have no regulations on our side of the house. We simply do not regulate the number of tourists, which does not mean we do not regulate certain behaviors. In the status quo, we see that regulation of behaviors is happening. A. Barcelona is banning Airbnbs, which rebutts all their point about housing prices. B. As we have seen in Copenhagen and Japan, they are offering perks like free lunches for tourists who use public transportation, who participate in cleanup activities, or support local businesses. Also, it rebuts the whole environment part. D, or we see that they are limiting the hours where alcohol can be bought to reduce bad behavior. E, we also see that there are stricter regulations and are being implemented, and there are increased fines for littering or damaging cultural sites, which are directly used for resuscitation or upkeep the very same. So these regulations are voting issues and popular among locals, which is the reason they are implemented.

Moving up to my first argument, the lack of viable alternative industries. We see this because of geographic constraints. Most of these countries simply do not have anything else to offer. So they have no minerals to mine, they have infertile land, they have multiple regions that are hard to access. Prop would need to explain why any ship is feasible and most countries would have the geographical ability. So second, there's no incentives for companies to establish themselves in these regions. A, in many countries you have comparatively higher tax rates and workers' rights. For example, Ireland, which is a tax hub and has very low tax rates compared to any other European country or Asian country. B, therefore, it is very easy for companies to move to a place where they don't pay taxes, like Ireland, for example, or Bangladesh, where you don't have any workers' rights. So in countries like Italy, it is way harder to establish yourself. Our third point is investor trust. Because there are tourism-specific investments, you have first a lack of high-speed internet, you have lack of heavy-duty roads, and your priorities easy and quick to build roads for tourist purposes. You have lack of industrial ports because beaches were prioritized. Four, you have localized skills and knowledge gap. Hali specializes workforce which needs to be re-educated to fit in a new industry. A. The workforce in these tourist-centric regions has developed skills specifically tailored to the tourism industry. Tour guides, hotel managers and cultural event coordinators possess skills that are directly tied to local tourism. So B. There is a lack of knowledge for new sectors. Developing alternative industries would require new skills and expertise that the local population currently lacks, for example, programming, mining or fishing. This is expensive and relies on the cooperation of the local people which is not guaranteed. We believe the fear of economic instability bothers the willingness and the ability of individuals to invest in learning skills. This means even if taxes and worker's rights would not be the problem, the local infrastructure and population will. We think it is unlikely that government should be able to attract and lobby companies and investors to move there. Historically, they are a huge competitive disadvantage against other countries who have worked on this relationship for decades and also they have way less to offer them because infrastructure, as I already mentioned, wasn't built and the knowledge was focused on tourism. This means that investors are not going to want to invest before these accommodations are built. And without investment, it is unlikely they will be able to build them. Because at the same time, the tourist countries are missing out on their biggest income, which is tourism. Especially if we look at the investment on a comparative, we are losing out on massive amounts of money. Currently, there is high investor trust in these regions because they have huge amounts of people coming in and the direction is increasing. Before I move on to my second argument, I will take it away.

Argument two, massive unemployment and economic regression. How does this happen? We have direct job losses. The tourism industry directly employs millions in sectors such as hospitality, transportation and retail. Significantly reductions in numbers mean significant amount of people will lose their jobs. There are less customers, less visitors, and less clients. So we also have indirect job losses because tourism supports numerous of other industries such as agriculture, this means food supplies for restaurants, and manufacturing goods for tourists. The loss of tourism would ripple through the supply chain. Also, third point is financial burden on the state. We would have massive unemployment benefits and business support needed. The state would need to provide unemployment benefits to displaced workers and provide business and previous business owners. This would strain public finances. This would require reallocating budget resources and impacting public services like healthcare and education. This is especially bad at the same time you significantly limit the biggest income source of the government, which is tourism. So, then we have a psychological and social impact. The fear and uncertainty. Even a slow implementation of tourist limits would create fear and uncertainty among the local population, undermining confidence in economic stability. This is crucial because the development of new industries is dependent on people spending money on this new industry and supporting its development. Why will this not be the case? A. People fear the unknown. They have worked in tourism for decades. Their whole family is specialized in it. This means when the government passes this policy, they will fear for their existence even if the government promises unemployment benefits or other compensation. First, people are often mistrustful of politicians and promises because they are rarely keep them. Second, also they cannot imagine how else the government could get money if not through tourism. This leads to people behaving extremely risk-averse, and they will only spend money on their very basic necessaries because they are saving money for hard times to come. This includes additional education. So note that the basic for economic growth is that people are willing to spend money on goods and services. The more people spend, the more money is circulated and added to the economy. This means that people can have jobs and pay employees. If the amount of money is now significantly restricted because we limit tourism significantly, people start hoarding and saving money rather than spending. This leads to a nationwide regression. This means even if some other industry was planned to develop, it will not be able to do so because people will be unwilling to spend money on goods and services from that industry. And investors will not want to invest in a regressive economy because it is extremely unstable and violent. Never be proud of your course. I'm going to ask you to not hold this. Wonderful. I will start my speech in three, two, one.

Panel, something that we feel is very important to note here on Team Proposition is that the reason why we are talking about this motion right now, the reason why we are talking about limiting the amount of tourists that can visit these major tourist destinations is because of the fact that in status quo, we are facing over tourism, which is something that team opposition doesn't seem to want to acknowledge.

The problem right now that we are facing is that there are far too many people going to these places. Yes, these major tourist destinations rely heavily on tourism. However, right now, the reason why so many people and so many locals are... Why these tourists are facing backlash from locals is because of the fact that there are far too many of them. They have created so many problems, they have created so much erosion, they have created so much disturbance within these cities that the locals simply cannot live their life. And even if the major cities do get some amount of profits from it, at this point it is far too unsustainable,

not only for these cities, but also for the environment, and that is why we here in Team Proposition are so happy to propose. So, first of all, in my speech I will firstly be going over a bit of rebuttal,
firstly going over a bit of rebuttal, and then going into our second substantive, which is reshaping travel culture and combating climate change through that.

So, first of all, when it comes to team opposition, they are quite clearly heavily focused on the economies of these major cities and the economies of these countries, right? Understandably so, because it seems like if you were to limit tourists majorly, then these cities would face immense amounts of problems, especially when it comes to something like job loss. However, we here in Team Proposition do not believe that is true. Number one, they claim that with limiting the amount of tourists that come in, a lot of people who have invested their skills and time into tourism would then have to leave the industry. However, that is not true because of what I noted earlier, which is that we are facing over-tourism, not just tourism.

We are not just limiting tourism, we are limiting over-tourism because right now it is unsustainable. The reason why we do not believe that there will be major economic job loss is due to the fact that these industries can still exist. These industries can still exist and thrive mainly due to the fact that there will still be many tourists. There will still be millions amount of tourists to these major tourist destinations because even though we are limiting them, that does not... Even though we are limiting them, we have to remember that we are talking about tens of millions, hundreds of millions of people who are coming into these places. Yes, we are significantly limiting them, but even having them, but even having the amount of tourists that come in, we remind you, this still means that there's tens of millions of people coming into these places. Not to mention that with these limitations, what we also believe in type proposition is that it will incentivize people to not only come during peak tourist times, but also year round. Not to mention that one of the problems, team opposition claims that you do not have to limit the amount of people that come in and say that you can instead regulate behavior. However, we do not believe that is mutually exclusive to team opposition. We here can limit the amount of tourists and still regulate behavior as well. That is not something that is exclusive to their site, and thus we would disagree with their, and thus that is why we are still so heavily in our approach of limiting the amount of tourists that come into these destinations.

And so, I will now start on our substantive. So, our second argument is reshaping travel, travel culture, and combating climate change. So, what will tourists do now that there are these major restrictions? What will happen? We here in Team Proposition have identified approximately three types of travelers. Number one, those who will go anyway to these major tourist destinations, right? Number two, those who will go somewhere else, either within the country or within some other country or within their own country. And three, those who simply will not go. Number one, those who will go anyways. We have to remember that despite the fact that these restrictions still exist, despite the fact that we are putting restrictions on, people can still go to these locations. We have to remember the example of Venice, right? Venice has implemented these restrictions, but there are still millions of amateurs who go there every day. Who go there at all times, right? Simply because we are limiting the amount of tourists doesn't mean that they won't go. Not to mention that because we have this entrance fee, which team opposition doesn't seem to want to talk about, it means that we can still uphold the economy of the city, and we can still help these tourists, we can still help these tourist industries, and they will still get their money. Not to mention that with this entrance fee, we can also ensure that these major cultural sites can uphold themselves, that they have the money to invest into themselves so that they are not eroded due to the amount of tourists that go there. Not to mention that now that there is no more over-tourism, now that there is no more over-crowding, these natural sites and these very important cultural artifacts can stay and that they can stay and they will not be eroded due to the massive amounts of people that go there every day. For example, when it comes to the Greek islands, a very big problem with the Greek islands right now is that their vineyards are slowly dying, right? Because there's simply so many people going there every day. There's simply so many people visiting these sites every day. And it is estimated that by 2045, the Greek islands will no longer have vineyards, simply because of the fact that there are so many tourists that go there all the time, who stomp on those places, who stomp on them, make the soil worse, and generally do not let the vineyards breathe. Which is not just destroying the natural beautiful sights of these islands, but also destroying a wine industry.

That is why we believe that it is so important to limit these tourists. Then, when we look at the people who go somewhere else, right, team opposition is very worried about the economic loss that may happen from this. However, we remind you, panel, that we are only talking about major tourist destinations. Now that people cannot or do not want to go to major tourist destinations, they can still go to other places in the country. They can still go to smaller towns. They can still travel to other places, meaning that even if they do not go to Paris, they can go to other places in France. A lot of people want to go to Paris because it's French, right? Because they see it as the French capital. Because they see it as the culture capital of France. However, now that they might not want to go to these places because of these restrictions, it's still very possible that those people who wanted to go to Paris because it's French culture will still be interested in going to other places in France, meaning that these since it's still very possible that those people who wanted to go to Paris because it's French culture will still be interested in going to other places in France, meaning that these jobs that the opposition is so worried about can simply continue in these smaller locations, which will now also have more tourists in them. Then, when it comes to the group three type of people who simply will not go, we believe that, yes, well, it is very important to talk about these cities and the major economic impacts that happens within these cities. We also believe that one of the major things that we have to talk about is the fact that climate change is ever getting worse, right? Climate change is only worsening. And what we have to do is try and combat it in any way that we can. And something that we have to remember is that in order to make big change, we first have to take small steps, right? And we believe that limiting the amount of people who can go to these first destinations, limiting travel in general, is a very good way of taking that first step. Because one of the major reasons of climate change is due to the fact that we are simply, is that we are consuming too much, we are spending too much, we are living these extravagant lives without thinking about what it does to the ecosystem, without thinking about what it does to these areas. And this small change of limiting who can go can in the future lead to bigger precedents. Not to mention that this small change is fixing a massive issue for locals, right? As we talked about within our first speech, it is fixing the problem of overcrowding, it is fixing the problem of these places being too expensive, it is fixing the problem of locals not being able to properly live their lives in these cities where they grew up, in these cities in which they pay taxes to, in these cities in which they have so much emotional attachment to. We believe that this is one of the best ways in order to ensure that not only these cities have the best upkeep for themselves, but also that the locals can stay within their communities and can have this national pride within their beautiful places. And because of all these reasons, we are so happy to propose, because we believe that even with these small steps, we can make big changes. Even with these small steps, we can do so much good within the world not only for the cities for locals but also for the environment thank you All right. We don't limit people, we limit hearts.

Let me start my speech with a lot of rebuttal before I go into my own. First, rebuttal on how you don't think unemployment will happen because they won't leave the industry. You significantly have less tourists because you limit them. This means you have significantly less workers. These major destinations heavily rely on the tourism sector, and the millions of tourists they are missing will also result in millions of workers being now unemployed, which is a huge harm to these locals you characterize as the most vulnerable and important stakeholders. So, you also point out that your entrance fee is enough for the economy, but you agree that millions of tourists are less on your side, so how high would your entrance fee have to be? A million times as high? This is just simply unrealistic on your side, and you are not facing the economical harms that my first speaker has mentioned quite thoroughly. Second of all, I think you agree that regulations can mitigate many of the harms. Then why would you voluntarily face the huge economic harms of significantly limiting the tourism if you could also mitigate these harms with the regulations and penalties for violation or reward programs for good behavior that we have mentioned in our speech.

Second point of rebuttal on the pricing being spiked by mass tourism. I told you on my POI this is simply untrue and locals are actually profiting from charging more to the tourists because the spheres where tourists and citizens compete for services is limited. What do I mean by that? First of all, different consumption patterns lead to limited overlap in high-demand goods. For example, tourists don't buy a significant quantity of basic goods or utilities, but rather go to fancy restaurants, souvenirs, and local artifacts. There is no shortage in the goods the locals actually need, which means the price stays quite constant. Second of all, in the rare case that they do compete, as you mentioned, housing and transport, there are easy implementations on our side taken to separate the competition. First of all, differentiate it through a pricing system, where, for example, citizens and local students have passes in public transport to pay less. Politicians that implement this, as my first speaker has explained, are extremely popular, which means this issue will be likely solved through voting. Second, tourists just pay more for attractions, like fish markets in Barcelona, taxis, restaurants in Asia, or Thailand's national parks, which means the revenue is reinvested in the same industry, so the infrastructure or the buses or the drivers are just upgraded so the locals aren't harmed because this balances out due to the more money they get from the tourists. Third of all, tourists prefer convenience, so they will opt for private transport options like a rental car, and this reduces the strain on public transport, so there's not really an overlap. On the housing issue, tourists often seek accommodations near major attractions, not in the residential areas, so this is not an actual problem. Second, if too much overlap happens, measures will be taken, as we see in Barcelona, banning Airbnb, and then government will likely implement seams to offer registered housing offers for the tourists, so they can, again, control the accessibility and pricing and free of housing for the locals. So this is, once again, mitigated. And even in the worst case where locals now have to drive a bit further to get to the next big local store, the money and benefits they earn from selling to all these high volumes of mass tourists more expensively just simply outweighs this minor possible part. Now, on

the point of vulnerable locals, we have to focus on where the delta is between mass tourism and your side of tourism. On your side, we have basically exclusively large chains like the Crowne Plaza, Hilton, McDonald's, that still exist because of market dominance and economies of scale. Comparatively, on our side, we additionally have support and opportunity for small and family-run businesses, hotels, and restaurants. Why is this? First of all, this bill will perfect. When major hotels are crowded, fully booked, or too expensive due to high demand, tourists turn to smaller local businesses. This only happens with tourism because of this high threshold. Second of all, economies of scale. Shades offer competitive prices and consistent quality, which small businesses can simply not match without the high volume of tourists frequenting their stores and restaurants and hotels every day. Furthermore, the extended tourism reach, which leads to infrastructure improvements and economic growth in the proximity, which extends beyond the major destinations to nearby smaller towns and coastal areas, as we see in Dubrovnik, where the tourists also go to see the surrounding coastline, but still have Dubrovnik as the main incentive to go there in the first place. Furthermore, reductions in mass urban migration that happens due to this because the establishment of transport lines to these surrounding areas reduces the need and burden for residents to migrate to urban centers in order for better opportunities. So they can commute easily, and this spillover effect also gives them jobs in more places. And these points specifically address your most vulnerable stakeholder. You think the problem for them is overcrowding, but the problem is poverty and unemployment that you cause on your side.

Now, on your point on environmental destruction. First of all, if tourism exists on both sides, how does the shift in environmental improvement happen on your side? This is the quality versus quantity thing again, where we explain to you that we have regulations that specifically address the biggest harms that tourists cause and on the other hand we have the resources due to the tax revenue from tourism and incentive and incentive to enforce better um like environmental sustainability because we also want to make this place nicely livable for locals and tourists now rebuttal on limits being beneficial for tourists this is simply not true because first of all on scale you are excluding so many of the people you are visiting. Second of all, it's not beneficial because you lack the high volume of tourist revenue which is necessary to establish and invest and maintain the infrastructure, which I will go into my argument. And then it is just simply more important for the locals. Last point of rebuttal I want to go into before I go into my argument is the culture point. First of all, there is the incentive to keep the culture because it makes it attractive both for tourists and locals. Second, we need the money to get generated from tourism to maintain and even live out this culture. For example, Mexico has cultural festivals where tourists and locals can enjoy the side-by-side, but the locals need the money from tourism to even live and be able to enjoy this. Now, on to my argument why massive loss of infrastructure for current infrastructure and future projects happen. Well, we're losing the tax revenue that is exclusive to tourism because, first of all, they majorly rely on tourism in these destinations, and second, due to the inherent locality of tourism, which means that they cannot relocate to avoid taxes because they're actually specifically located there. And tourism just simply has a high tax revenue because there are so various channels. Hotel taxes, overnight fees, sale taxes on goods and services, and entry fees to attractions. So this is not like a one-time thing as your access fee, but rather the tourists every day going for breakfast, lunch, dinner, or hotel, and buying some expensive souvenirs on the way. So what will the impact be on your side? You simply have a loss of investment as well as a loss of tax revenue and thereby reduced government funding. My first speaker has already explained to you why this is detrimental to the people facing unemployment because the government no longer has the budget and the funds to help them. And second, how this leads to them being super scared and insecure to join with any other sectors, even though these other sectors are unlikely to happen anyway due to all the reasons why tourism is exclusive to these places. But going deeper into my question. Is the state government not so dependent on tourism because they don't deteriorate during the off-season? Of course they are. Major tourist destinations are major tourist destinations. This means they are majorly and significantly reliant on tourism to fund them and to make them, like, that is their main income area. So, where does this income lead to? This income currently is being used for infrastructure development, because mass tourism necessitates improvement for infrastructure, roads, airports, electricity and life airlines, as well as sanitation and waste. As well as, like, healthcare and emergency. You mentioned that crowded hospitals are a problem, but at least we have hospitals on our side because tourism is generating the money to actually build these things in the first place. Second of all, tourism is an incentive for enhanced safety measures because the incentive is on the one hand, the locals want to protect their national heritage and they want a positive reputation for more tourists to come, and they have the capability due to the tax revenue from tourism that we have exclusively on our side on this scale.
